node.title: She Fell for the Art, Then for the Artist
node.description: A neighbor introduced Becky Headen to Tony Hernandezâ€™s artwork in 2001. Twelve years later, they had a first date.
node.content: ["Rebekah Headen fell in love with Tony Hernandez years before she actually met him. Not only that, it was love at first sight.", "\u201cWhere did you get that beautiful painting?\u201d Ms. Headen, 57, who is known as Becky, recalled asking a neighbor who had moved from Atlanta to Charlotte, N.C., where she lives, in 2001.", "\u201cIt\u2019s a Tony Hernandez,\u201d the neighbor said of the painting of a WWI airplane with a fish hook hanging out of one of the wings. \u201cHe\u2019s an extremely talented artist who lives in Atlanta.\u201d", "Ms. Headen\u2019s interest in Mr. Hernandez, 56, as an artist increased significantly when he enjoyed a brush with fame following the release of \u201cDrops of Jupiter,\u201d the second album produced by the rock band Train, which featured his artwork.", "\u201cThat was huge for him,\u201d said Ms. Headen, who received a bachelor\u2019s degree in studio art from the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, and works as a talent strategy manager for the Hendrick Automotive Group in Charlotte.", "\u201cI fell in love with his style,\u201d added Ms. Headen, who at the time was married and raising two young boys. \u201cI was like OK, I\u2019m going to get one of those paintings one day.\u201d", "In 2002, she did just that, commissioning a painting by Mr. Hernandez through Hidell Brooks, an art gallery in Charlotte, as a Father\u2019s Day gift for her then husband. (Titled \u201cInhook,\u201d it was completed in 2003.)", "Ms. Headen followed her order with her very first call to Mr. Hernandez, with whom she confirmed shipping details before learning that he is a history buff who has drawn inspiration from the lives of children who grew up during the Holocaust, as well as those who struggled through the Great Depression, especially in the ghettos of the Bronx where his grandparents lived.", "An Atlanta native, Mr. Hernandez attended Georgia Tech before leaving college to pursue a career in painting. His works, mostly of children during the Holocaust and Great Depression, are currently on display at numerous art galleries, including the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco and the Bronx Museum of the Arts.", "[Click here to binge read this week\u2019s featured couples.]", "The two connected again in 2004, this time in person, at a gallery opening in Charlotte.", "\u201cHe was such a nice guy,\u201d Ms. Headen said, \u201cthough he did seem to mumble a lot.\u201d", "After that, they would not see each other until 2013.", "Early that year, Ms. Headen, who by then was divorced, went to Chicago with several friends, one of whom mentioned that she had a friend who was single and talented and that his name was Tony Hernandez.", "\u201cI thought to myself, \u2018This could be very interesting,\u2019\u201d Ms. Headen said.", "Mr. Hernandez, also divorced, reached out to Ms. Headen at the suggestion of their mutual friend in June 2013. They eventually began a conversation that led to a first date to watch the Sept. 1 episode of Breaking Bad, their favorite television show.", "Mr. Hernandez rode his Harley motorcycle in the rain from Atlanta to Charlotte to meet Ms. Headen for the date.", "\u201cI had no negative thoughts as to why I shouldn\u2019t go, which is rare for me,\u201d Mr. Hernandez said. \u201cSo I thought maybe it was meant to be.\u201d", "In February 2018, after years of dating long-distance, Mr. Hernandez moved to Charlotte to live with Ms. Headen. (Her two sons were living on their own by then.) The pair became engaged roughly three years later, on Feb. 14, 2021.", "\u201cI found Becky to be the sum of so many beautiful things,\u201d Mr. Hernandez said. \u201cShe was beautiful, smart and understanding, especially about the fact that I spend more time with my painting than I do with her.\u201d", "The couple was married Oct. 29 at the home of their friends Kim and Ed Seeger on Little Stono Island, in Charleston, S.C. Lauren Stines, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated before 10 fully vaccinated guests, who included Ms. Headen\u2019s sons Franklin, 27, and James, 24.", "\u201cWe connect on so many different levels,\u201d the groom said of the bride a week after their wedding. \u201cShe fell in love with my art long before she fell in love with me, and I don\u2019t think we could have happened any other way.\u201d"]
